awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Urban Vector-Borne Disease Transmission Demands Advances in Spatiotemporal Statistical Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
Statistical analysis of partially-observed, nonlinear, stochastic spatiotemporal systems is a methodological challenge. Many existing inference algorithms suffer from a "curse of dimensionality" that prohibits their applicability to models describing interacting dynamic processes occurring within and between many spatial locations. New algorithms will be developed, and shown in theory and in practice to advance capabilities for spatiotemporal data analysis. This methodological research will be carried out in the context of addressing a public health concern, transmission of dengue virus. Global incidence of dengue has risen 30-fold over the past fifty years, with notable geographical expansion in South and Central America. The municipality of Rio de Janeiro is a focal point for dengue transmission in this region. Spatiotemporal data on dengue cases in Rio de Janeiro will be analyzed, together with data on human movement, temperature, and rainfall. Policy decisions for the detection, control, and potential eradication of infectious diseases are informed by model-based understanding of disease transmission. Improved understanding of the spatiotemporal dynamics of disease transmission will have implications for improvements in disease control. Mathematical models will be developed to describe spatiotemporal dynamics of dengue transmission, and the novel statistical methodology will be used to link these models to the data from Rio de Janeiro.

Spatiotemporal partially-observed Markov process models provide a framework for formulating and answering questions relating spatiotemporal data to an underlying stochastic dynamic process. Statistically efficient inference involves integrating out over possible values of the latent process, a task known as filtering. Except when the system is approximately linear and Gaussian, filtering spatiotemporal models is challenging. One algorithm developed in this project will address the curse of dimensionality by guiding Monte Carlo particles toward important regions in the latent variable space. Another algorithm will combine many weak, independent filters to give a global filtering solution. Disease transmission systems, which are highly nonlinear and stochastic and are imperfectly observable, will be used to motivate and demonstrate the capabilities of the new algorithms. Specifically, models will be developed for the dynamics of dengue transmission in the major metropolis of Rio de Janeiro.  Spatiotemporal stochastic epidemiological models will be used to examine the role of human mobility, host immunity, and climate variability in the context of a heterogeneous socioeconomic landscape.  A particular goal is to identify locations that function as sources of infection critical to disease invasion and persistence as well as those that act as sinks incapable of sustained local transmission.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
A key outcome from NSF DMS-1761603 was a sequence of papers developing three new statistical theory and methodology to extend capabilities for modeling and inference for partially observed, nonlinear, stochastic spatiotemporal processes. Critically, these were developed in the context of collaboration with NSF DMS-1761612 on spatiotemporal investigations of transmission of the dengue virus. This helped us work toward methods are scientifically applicable, both at a fundamental theoretical level and at the practical level of software implementation and data analysis methodology. Thus, both the statistical and scientific sides of the project worked synergistically.


All three of the new algorithms construct an ensemble of values of the state of the system, representing uncertainty about the known state of the system given the available data. This conditional distribution of latent states is called the filter distribution, and each member of the ensemble is called a particle, so these methods are generically called particle filters. 


1. The guided intermediate resampling filter (2020, Statistics & Computing) enables maximum likelihood inference for simulation-based models, with theoretical and practical scaling properties that apply only under limited conditions.


2. Bagged filters (2022, Journal of the American Statistical Association) combine many simple filters to construct methodology which scales to larger spatiotemporal systems. This provides likelihood-based inference with an approximation error which can, in principle, be made arbitrarily small.


3. Iterated, perbured block particle filters (2023, Journal of Machine Learning Research) provides methodology with similar asymptotic theoretical support to bagged filters, but superior practical performance on the biological metapopulation models that provide the primary motivation for this research agenda. 


A design principle for all these new algorithms is that they should be implementable in a general software environment applicable to arbitrary choices of nonlinear, stochastic, dynamic models with spatial structure. This flexibility facilitates creative scientific model development. We developed such a software environment, distributed as the spatPomp package for the R programming language.


As mentioned above, this research involved sustained collaboration on dengue transmission dynamics with the Pascual group at University of Chicago. Scientific results from that half of the project (NSF DMS-1761612) are discussed in the corresponding outcome report. This research used our newly developed methods, providing a technology transfer that supported both scientific research and statistical methodology development.


This research agenda adds spatiotemporal capabilities to methods that saw extensive applications during the COVID-19 pandemic. It therefore builds capacity for improved modeling and inference for infectious diseases in future. The open-source software developed during the project makes these methods accessible to the research community. One postdoc, two PhD students and eight undergraduate students have been trained on these techniques during the project. 


Last Modified: 09/21/2023
Modified by: Edward L Ionides
